value.0: This elegantly carved chair is both functional and beautiful to look at. A very ornately engraved and enameled steel plate is affixed to the high back of the chair.  The plate bears the family crest of the Tinkerflame family.
Stuffed with tomes of all shapes and sizes, this bookcase stores a wealth of knowledge.

Lively raunchy music emanated through the beaded curtain. Smoke hung in various layers within the private booth. The small round table supported a couple of burning candles along with chalices of fruity wine and a tray of delictable eats. There also upon the table she turned, twisted and undulated in graceful fashion, avoiding all obstacles at her feet. The painted streaks in her hair and across her face glistened in the dim light. The glitter, powdered over her body, added to her heavenly form. She was a visual delight for the balding pudgy man, sitting upon the couch before her. When the current tune began to wane, she deftly moved from the table to the mans side. Taking his hand into hers, she gently brushed his palm with her fingers and began cooing into his ear. 

"I have never known anyone who has held such treasures within their hands" 
The man chortled at the fawning. "Yes...More than a kings ransom have passed through my clutches." He grasped tightly onto her fingers as his ego arose. "Now I wish to touch your treasures, my lovely sweet..." 
Pulling away from the man, she slipped easily from his grasp. Playfully waggling her finger at him "Ah, ah, ah...remember, you must say the magic words first." she coyly scolded as her other hand took up one of the fuller chalices and offered it to him. 
The man seemed disinclined at first, but as the lip of glass touched his, he opted to drink lest the wine spill about him. Placing the near empty chalice back upon the table, the buxom lady straddled the mans lap. Then leaning in close to enhance his view, she whispered into his ear. "Tell me the code...say the magic words." 
The mans eyes bugged as he clenched his hands into the couch. His mind realing from various heady scents, the enticing visual display and several glasses of wine. He burst forth aloud "Take the key unto the lock!". 
He continued panting as she shimmied into an upright position. With a wry grin upon her face she took hold of his hands and began guiding them about her more voluptuous parts. 
"This is what your master says for you to retrieve valuables from the vault?" she queried further. 
With the cat out of the bag, and being unable to discern any possible harm, the man could do little more than nod and stammer, "Yes!...Yes!...now, how about a kiss?" 
"Of course my dear...my vault is now open for you to freely access" she quipped, while arching backward to the table. Her hand reached out and took hold upon a small glass, hidden amongst the flagons and flowers. "But first...let us have another drink." 

The slender,scantilly clad woman stepped out from the beaded curtain. Her hair and makeup shimmered more brightly in the main hall. She took pause and glanced about at the myriad of men, from dregs to dandies, all partaking in some form of pleasure as vixens coaxed them into more drinks. Her eyes came to rest upon the guard standing just outside the archway she exited. Flashing him a quick smile, she nodded her head back toward the booth. "Your boss has had enough and is ready to go home." The lightly armored man turned and split open the curtain looking in. Entering the booth he began grumbling "Fat sot...gonna have to carry..." the rest was lost as the lady began making her way toward the front entrance. 

Few took notice of her as she gracefully weaved between the tables, not even those who clutched at her passing. Few took notice as her clothing became less revealing. Few took notice as a cape formed upon her shoulders. Few took notice as she stepped out the door into the icy night. 

Her breath dispersed and mingled into the chilly fog, thick upon the streets. Somewhere off the docks a bouy sang its warning song as it solemly danced upon the wakes. The merry revelry warmly poured out from behind her as she made one last glance back. Pulling the fur lined hood over her head, she turned down and away from the approaching clip-clop of a horse and cart. She made with haste, until another bouy joined the first in quiet unison. Glancing back once again and confident of her success, the same wry smile broke out on her face. Then it was gone as her form began to waiver and shimmer. Her body shrank by several centimeters...her delicate amber skin turned grey and gnarled...her elegant clothing turned to dusty work attire...her picturesque face faded leaving only a pair of grey eyes peering from his veiled ghutra. 

Oggling his retreat, the wirey diminutive man turned chuckling to himself. Then disappeared into the foggy night. 

A thousand other tales progressed throughout the streets, buildings and unseen places of Brosna. Until two nights later. 

The elderly gentleman adjusted his robe back down, then began preening himself in the mirror in preparation for bed. He gritted and displayed his teeth while brushing a comb through his full thick hair. Taking the comb to his moustache, he swiped it quickly a couple of times then came to a sudden stop. The candles aside the mirror flickered as a chill whisked in from the bedroom. His eyes darted toward the reflection of the door. Quietly placing the comb down, the man reached toward the nearby stand, grasping a jeweled dagger hidden amongst the towels and ointments. He crept toward the door unsheathing the blade. Knowing his house keeper had already turned down the bed he called out "Florence?...Is that you?" Hearing no sound or response he cautiously peered out into the master bedroom. Nothing seemed amiss except for the fluttering curtains and the window shifting back and forth in the frosty wind. Scowling ever so slightly the man made his way pass the still locked chamber door and around the massive canopy bed to the window. Thoughts of scolding his house keeper soon diminished as the sound of crystaline glass crunched under his foot. The old man had but a split moment to glance down at the rapidly rising reddish vapor spreading out about him. His body impacted solidly upon the floor. 

Consciousness began to creep back into the mans mind. Then suddenly he was quite taken aback as he literaly was looking at himself gazing into a mirror. Although the head was just right, he was clearly a half meter too short for the mans robe he was wearing. He tilted the small hand held mirror and noticed himself staring at him in bewilderment. 

"Awake so soon are you? The shortened version of himself asked. 
Turning to the man set up against the wall near his bed, he gestured his palm downward in a coaxing manner. "Struggle not, nor call out" he stated while turning the small handmirror to meet the trussled mans gaze. "A ward I have placed upon you. A ward of much power." 
The man glanced into the mirror and his eyes winced as his lips began to tremble. There he could see a strangely phosphorescent rune painted on his forehead. Reaching a hand upward toward his forhead his shorter self cautioned again. "Bestill yourself lest you destroy yourself. Call out or attempt to flee and the ward will burrow into your mind. Robbing you of sight first it will do, then leave you in gibbering madness." 
Nervously glancing at his palm, he slowly lowered it back to his side. "Smart and wise you are." A smile broke over the little mans face, then he pointed toward the still open window, as he continued. "Fret not for when the surface light strikes upon the pane, the magic will have faded." 
Pulling his hand back, the small man continued examing his face in the mirror and adjusting the oversized robe on his shoulders. 
In a quivering voice the elderly man whispered, "You will not get away with this." 
The shortened version of himself, seemingly satisfied with his appearance, put away the mirror. Then spoke, altering his voice as best he could to that of his captive. "Perhaps yes...perhaps no...but one can neither succeed or fail if one never tries." The sitting man was taken aback. The voice was still not quite is own, but the accent was near perfect. "Now, sit there quietly and the light will be here soon enough." With that he gathered up the extra length of his robe, made his way across the room and threw the man a wink as he exited out the chamber door. 

Slipping quiety unseen through the halls and downstairs, he made his way in through the back side of a large dining hall. A pair of guards stood just outside an archway at the opposite end. A quiet drone emitted from one, while the other managed to amuse himself with contents of his nose. Flitting under the tables edge, he adjusted the chair on the end, then climbed up and stood upon the seat. 

"Guard!" he called out in a cracked rasping voice. 
The one looked up then suddenly became alert. "Sir?" he responded turning into the archway, while sliding the end of his polearm across the floor, to nudge his partners foot. 
"Summon the accountant...and have someone fetch me some water." he continued to rasp. Both men saluted and exited out the through the arch. 
Briefly thereafter a servant entered through the rear with a tray holding a pitcher and glass. "Leave it and leave me." he ordered as the servant quietly obeyed. 

A muttering voice soon washed out the silence and into the hall the guards returned, preceded by a pudgy bald man. Though long since recovered from a nasty hangover, the bald fellow was still a bit groggy from having recently been wakened. "What is your need Lord?!" he badgered as he came to a stop near the midlength of the table. 
"I have just awakened from a most frightning nightmare." the man in the chair responded, while maintaining his posture in the poorly lit hall. 
"A nightmare?! If it is console of a nightmare, then you should call upon the herbalist or the seer!" the bald man fumed. "I was wakened in the middle of the night...!" 
"Be quiet!" the man in the chair shouted while pounding his arm onto the table. "It is I who am in discomfort, and it is you who can put me at ease." 
"I beg your pardon, Lord." he humbly replied. Now in his place he questioned further, "How is it that I may be of service to you?" 
Repositioning himself in the chair, the man cleared his throat and continued. "As I said, a nightmare has disturbed my senses and jolted me awake. In this dream a number of dark elves penetrated our vault and stole an item from its enclosure." 
"Lord, you know that is preposterous. There is no way such a thing could occur." the bald man assured. 
"None the less, you will go and fetch this item so that I may know it is secure, and I can feel at ease." the man said while placing one arm over his chest. 
"Very well, what piece am I to retreive from the vault?" the bald man increduously queried over what he was being asked to do. 
"There is a baton, about a half meter long." the man described while spreading his arms out in approximation. "It is inlaid with platinum and has a large ruby at one end with an adamantium nub..." 
"Yes, yes...I recall the piece." interjected the accountant. "We recently acquired it from some of our cellar clients at a fair price. Why would anyone want to steal that broken thing? It has no resellable value...we will in all likely-hood need to break it down and sell off the individual metals and gems to turn a profit. It has no magical properties, which is why the drow were willing to part with it." 
"Ahhh, but this item has power beyond mere magic, and you will bring it to me at once!", the sitting man exclaimed while clasping his hands together. 
The bald man stood for a moment, studying the man he served. Taking a brief step closer he asked, "My Lord, are you all right? You sound a bit..." 
The man in the chair slammed his arm onto the table again and shouted, "Of course I am not all right! I have just had my sleep disturbed by a nightmare that indicates our very securities may be at risk! Now for the last time go and fetch what I ask for!" 
The accountant stepped back and responded with a fluster, "Yes M'Lord, I will make with haste.", then stood stark still gazing with regard at the man commanding him. 
Moments continued to slip by as the bald man resolved not to budge. 
It was now or never for the little man in the chair. His hand raised and clasped over his mouth. Brushing down over his moustache and bringing it to rest on his chin he methodically spoke. "Take the key unto the lock." 
The bald man bowed his head, took a few steps back, "I will do as you have ordered.", then pirouetted and motioned to the guards before exiting through the arched door. 
A deep sigh filled the quiet hall. 

Soon the trio returned. The pudgy bald man made his way down the length of the table with a cheerfully feigned smile upon his face. "Good news M'Lord, good news!" he spouted, "Everything was secure, all security devices are still in place and the object you seek was right in its place." he continued while laying a tattered leather cylinder before the man in the chair. 
The moustached man reached out and slid the end of the rod from its container. A wide smile broke out over his face as he gently caressed his hand over it. 
"Lost for over six generations." he began to speak. "It was a pick of mighty power. Said to be able to carve through stone and enchantments like a remorhaz through a glacier. It was weilded by a great svirfneblin general against a horde of goblinkin. Broken while fending off an invasion of renegade yuan-ti." The man in the chair continued, while the bald man before looked upon him in bewilderment. "It was last rumored to have been kept hidden on a high priest of Callarduran imprisoned in an illithid slave kennel." He paused glancing up at the bald man. "Until they feasted on his brain." 
"The seer made no mention of any of this, are you certain of this M'Lord?" the bald man chimed in. 
"Certain of this most definately I am." The sitting mans voice began to revert to his own. Sliding the piece back into the leather case and clutching it tightly he finished, "Now, returned it is after so long away." 

Stepping back from the stranger before him the bald man became angered at his realizations. "Who are you?! What have you done with the master?!" he shouted out while signaling the guards to alertness. 
A cutting tearing sound filled the hall as a blade sliced down the front of the robe worn by the man in the chair. His face began to waiver and change turning black as pitch while his greying hair lengthened and turned the palest white. The bald man began stumbling back in fear at the transformation. A drow elf with a human skin cloak, fluttering wildly upon its shoulders, leapt up from the chair onto the table. Metal shards and bone were decoratively pierced about its flesh and blood ran from its mouth and dripped off its chin. The drow brandished a wicked dagger in the direction of the bald man screeching, "vel'uss else orn'la dos expect ulu double cross dos!" 

The bald man, suddenly stricken blind, was able to grasp back with his sanity and began shouting out, "Alarm! Alarm!" 
The two guards had already taken action, retrieving crossbows stashed in their alcoves. The raised up to take aim, as a bell sounded out elsewhere on the compound. The drow turned and hissed as its body became shifting and obscure. Bolts raced down the length of the table and pierced the high back chair at the other end. The bald man fell further back, stumbling about blindly, toward the archway as the two guards began to reload. Both were discombobulated from focusing on everything except the indistinct drow. 

The blurred form of black and white leapt from the table and out the back of the hall. It whizzed between more pairs of gaurds advancing from various hallways. Dashing back up the stairs, another volley of bolts flew harmlessly by. The first two guards continued their pursuit as a guard of higher rank began barking out commands and pointing in all directions. The drow returned to the master bedroom and made a direct path to the still open window. Its form coalesced back into focus before the man still crouched by the side of his bed. The old man struggled with his desire to scream out and his want for maintaining his faculties. The drow threw a wry grin and a wink at the man as it sprung up onto the window sill. A hand pick deftly replaced the dagger in hand, to which the drow hooked onto a rope tied just outside. The guards burst in loosing another volley out the window, as the drow repelled down to a tree growing in the courtyard. The guards advanced to the window as more guards arrived to the scene. Torches began lighting up and moving about the yard. The drow dashed and leaped, catching the top of the wall with its pick. It pulled itself up sharpley then flipped over and outside. 

The guards at the window pointed and shouted out, "The fiend is over the back north-east corner!". The torches shifted directions to new courses. The old man layed in a tight ball, resisting all attempts from those trying to help him. 

A group of four guards raced around the outside and around the corner. They came across a thin crippled man struggling to get back up on his crutch. One guard carrying a torch reached down and forcefully helped the man back onto his only leg. "Did you see a dark elf pass this way peasant?!" The guard quickly loosed his grip upon the man and recoiled staring at his hand in horror. 
The short man was wrapped from head to toe in swaddling with only his thin nose and blood shot eyes exposed. Much of his rags were soiled and stained from open sores. He sputtered to the demands pointing off with his fingerless hand, "Et wen tha way." Turning his palm back to the gaurds he stammered "Spa a coin?" 
One of the other guards shoved the paralyzed one and yelled out at the others, "Move on after him! Before he gets away!" 
"I touched him...I touched him..." the one continued to mutter as the three moved off. 
The remaining guard prodded the haft end of his voulge into the diseased man. "You, shove off and begon from here leper, or I will personally take a torch to you when I return!" he commanded before sprinting off after the others. 

The thin man cowered until the guards had gone. Then he hobbled off on his crutch, out the back alley and onto the street. He limped a few blocks away from the still excited abode. Suddenly a hand pick spun with precision in his fingerless hand. Catching the edge of the steel plate in the street with it, he opened the cover from the manhole. Dropping down into the sewers, the thin cripple made his way along several tunnels. Coming to a rest, he peered off in both directions. Seeing little more than darkness, he reached to the tunnel wall and shifted a brick loose from its place. A small section of bricks twisted open, revealing a narrow rough hewn tunnel behind it. On the other side, the mans form waivered and shrank as he pressed upon a stone, sealing the enclosure behind him. 

Peeling open the leather case, the darkness took on a feint red glow. His left eye, glinting with a ruby spark, nearly popped from his skull. Covering it back up, he spoke, "Once again you will inspire warrior and worker alike." 

Then it and the svirfneblin disappeared into the darkness.

This lengthy dry ledger of figures and expenditures boggles the mind.  Detailing among other things a large purchase of potions from one Drugrigrin Roido, the ledger appears to have been most recently maintained by Chefen Tincture Tinkerflame.  The signature bears a modestly theatrical flourish.

The Svirfnebli are the only race that have willingly settled deep in the underdark. Not like the Duergar or the drow (Ilythrii) who were driven down there, banished by their good aligned counterparts. 

It was the svirfnebli deity Callarduran Smoothhands, who led these gnomes to settle in these regions as he wished to add diversity among the gnomes. In the underdark they prospered, mostly in peace. Relying on their illusionary defenses and neutrality. Trading with goodaligned underdark inhabitants, such as Ellistrae followers. But this didn't stop occational raids by enslavers (drow, duergar and illithids). 

Deep beneath the realm of Nordock, there once was a grand hidden city called Gibblemethin. Wealthy and rich from its trades from the trading routes to the dwarfs of Blackhill. 

But there was a war between drows and the good dwarfs, a war where the neutral Svirfnebli were forced to take a stand. And they chose to aid the dwarfs. Which of course led to the drow's campaign being twarted. 

For this the enraged noble drows of Chaulssin planned their revenge on the hidden Gibblemethin. It was just a matter of time before a temporary alliance between the Mindflayers (Illithids) and the Drow were forged. And with the illithids help they managed to locate the hidden city. .. The city stood no chance against the elite drow troops, their conjured fiends and the illithid powers. The drows got their revenge, the illithids got what was left of the city. A fair deal for this dark alliance. 

The majority of the survivors were enslaved by either drows or illithids, or sacrified to unholy gods. Those who did escape scattered over the realm of Nordock. Often mistaken for being sickly looking gnomes, The first generation found a life in poverty and shy solitude. Picking up and gathering pieces of their shattered heritage. 

That is til one day nearly 200 surface years later, when a new light of hope was kindled. With their collective effort, Mak'a'nor was founded. An outpost between two worlds. A place for trading, mining and development of trinkets. 

Being still very small, Mak'a'nor's main defense is a 2 foot thick iron gate. The town itself having little capability to support any military force. So they hoped that the drows and duergars would leave them alone if they remained small and unthreatening. 

.. They were mistaken. A small town like that is an easy mark for enslavers to raid. And thus, there was a desperate call for heroes.

This larger than life statue is carved in the amazing likeness of Roidoc Merudo Weil, former Chefen and founder of the Mak'a'nor Mining Co.  At the base of the statue inlaid in fine gold is the inscription, "Leader, defender, and friend.  May he find his way to the Deep Brother in the Golden Hills."

Unlike many other features of this room, the statue appears to have been meticulously maintained and cared for, a final devotion from those with whom he served.
One leg seems slightly loose. You wonder how long the stool will last.
One leg seems slightly loose. You wonder how long the stool will last.
